StringWithMarkup.String: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources.

It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute. More information can be found at https://sor.epa.gov/sor_internet/registry/substreg/LandingPage.do

StringWithMarkup.String: Acute Exposure Guideline Levels for Airborne Chemicals

nodes.description: AEGL :: Acute exposure guideline levels (AEGLs) describe the human health effects from once-in-a-lifetime, or rare, exposure to airborne chemicals. Used by emergency responders when dealing with chemical spills or other catastrophic exposures, AEGLs are set through a collaborative effort of the public and private sectors worldwide.

Biologicals :: The Biological Substance List is an aggregate of biological substances from other substance lists within the SRS. The list includes plants, animals, fungi, and microbe species that are subject to environmental regulations or are of interest to EPA.. Each record includes the species name paired with its appropriate Taxonomic Serial Number (TSN), if available. TSNs are assigned by the Integrated Taxonomic Information System [www.itis.gov] (ITIS). ITIS is an online database of authoritative taxonomic information maintained by the US Geological Survey, the Smithsonian Institution and various partners. Search the TSN in ITIS to obtain more related taxonomic information for the record.
Decon Portfolio Agents :: These are the agents that are currently entered into the EPA Decontamination Portfolio

EPA :: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is an agency of the United States government.  Its mission is to protect human health and to safeguard the natural environment.  To fulfill that mission EPA maintains data systems about regulated substances and identifies categories of chemical substances that are subject to environmental regulations.
Isotopes :: Isotopes of radionuclides
OAR_PFAS :: Perfluoroalkyl substances
OPPT_PFAS :: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are a group of man-made chemicals that includes PFOA, PFOS, GenX, and many other chemicals.

StringWithMarkup.String: ORD_CompTox Per- and PolyFluoroAlkyl Substances- all substances

nodes.description: CompTox_PFAS-all substances :: The Dashboard is a one-stop-shop for chemistry, toxicity and exposure information for over 760,000 chemicals. Data and models within the Dashboard also help with efforts to identify chemicals of most need of further testing and reducing the use of animals in chemical testing.

StringWithMarkup.String: ORD_CompTox Per- and PolyFluoroAlkyl Substances-Undefined Structure

nodes.description: Comptox_PFAS-Undefined Structure :: The Dashboard is a one-stop-shop for chemistry, toxicity and exposure information for over 760,000 chemicals. Data and models within the Dashboard also help with efforts to identify chemicals of most need of further testing and reducing the use of animals in chemical testing. List of PFAS chemicals without explicit structures - polymers and other UVCB chemicals (under constant curation and expansion)

StringWithMarkup.String: ORD_CompTox Per- and PolyFluoroAlkyl Substances-defined structure

nodes.description: Comptox_PFAS-defined structure :: The Dashboard is a one-stop-shop for chemistry, toxicity and exposure information for over 760,000 chemicals. Data and models within the Dashboard also help with efforts to identify chemicals of most need of further testing and reducing the use of animals in chemical testing. List consists of all DTXSID records with a structure assigned, and where the structure contains the substructure RCF2CFR'R' (R cannot be H). The substructure filter is designed to be simple, reproducible and transparent, yet general enough to encompass the largest set of structures having sufficient levels of fluorination to potentially impart PFAS-type properties.

PBT :: EPA has finalized enhanced reporting requirements that focus on toxic chemicals which persist and bioaccumulate in the environment. These are known as persistent bioaccumulative toxic (PBT) chemicals. EPA is increasing the utility of the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) to the public by adding PBT chemicals to the TRI list and by lowering the reporting thresholds for some of these chemicals. Toxic chemicals that persist and bioaccumulate are of particular concern because they remain in the environment for significant periods of time and concentrate in the organisms exposed to them. These PBT chemicals have the potential to cause serious human health and environmental effects resulting from low levels of release and exposure that would not be reported under the thresholds that apply to other toxic chemicals under Section 313.

RSL :: The RSL website is now the source of screening levels for all the EPA regions. The RSL tables provide comparison values for residential and commercial/industrial exposures to soil, air, and tapwater (drinking water). The unified use of the RSLs, to screen chemicals at Superfund sites, promotes national consistency. Here you will find tables of risk-based screening levels, calculated using the latest toxicity values, default exposure assumptions and physical and chemical properties, and a calculator where default parameters can be changed to reflect site-specific risks.

SCIL :: The Safer Chemical Ingredients List (SCIL) is a list of chemical ingredients, arranged by functional-use class, that the Safer Choice Program has evaluated and determined to be safer than traditional chemical ingredients. This list is designed to help manufacturers find safer chemical alternatives that meet the criteria of the Safer Choice Program.

SCDM :: The Superfund Chemical Data Matrix (SCDM) is a source for factor values and screening concentration benchmarks that can be applied when evaluating potential National Priorities List (NPL) sites using the Hazard Ranking System (HRS). Factor values are part of the HRS mathematical equation for determining the relative threat posed by a hazardous waste site and reflect hazardous substance characteristics, such as toxicity and persistence in the environment, substance mobility and the potential for bioaccumulation. Screening concentration benchmarks are environment- or health-based substance concentration limits, including some developed by or used in other EPA regulatory programs. SCDM contains HRS factor values and screening concentration benchmarks for hazardous substances that are frequently found at sites evaluated using the HRS, as well as the physical, chemical and radiological data used to calculate those values.

StringWithMarkup.String: Synonyms Provided by Submitters to the TSCA Inventory

nodes.description: TSCA INV SYN :: Synonyms Provided by Submitters to the TSCA Inventory
WDNR :: Substances compiled by WDNR

StringWithMarkup.String: Wisconsin Vascular Flora Partial Working List- January 2015

nodes.description: Wisconsin VFPWL :: Wisconsin Vascular Flora Partial Working List as of January 2015
List type: EPA Application/System

2012 CDR :: This list contains chemicals that were reported to EPA's 2012 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  Companies that manufacture (including import) certain chemicals at certain volumes in the U.S. must report to EPA every four years through its CDR.  The vast majority of chemicals on this 2012 CDR list needed to be reported, but some of these chemicals were not required to be reported.  EPA uses the CDR data to support many health, safety, and environmental protection activities.

AQS :: The Air Quality System is a data management system that contains ambient air quality measurements and descriptive information about the locations where the ambient air quality data are collected.  These data are collected by State, local and tribal agencies who periodically upload them to AQS.  The ambient air quality data in AQS are used to track progress in implementing the national air pollution control program.  The data in AQS are required to be reported to EPA (40 CFR 58.35) under the authorization of the Clean Air Act Amendments.  AQS data are used primarily by EPA and State/local/Tribal air agencies. For example, AQS data are used  by EPA to determine non-attainment areas for the pollutants that have national ambient air quality standards (NAAQS), for trends analysis, modeling, and providing the public with information about the cleanliness of the air in various areas and for various air quality reports for Congress and others.

CAMEO Chemicals is an emergency response and planning tool.  This program includes an extensive chemical database with critical response information for thousands of chemicals, as well as a reactivity prediction tool that allows you to see what hazards might occur if chemicals in your collection were mixed together.  CAMEO Chemicals is available as a website, mobile website, and a desktop application.  CAMEO Chemicals is part of a software suite of programs called CAMEO (Computer-Aided Management of Emergency Operations).  The CAMEO suite also includes a hazard modeling tool (ALOHA), a mapping program (MARPLOT), and two database applications (CAMEOfm and Tier2 Submit) designed to assist with the data management requirements under the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA, also known as SARA Title III).  The CAMEO suite programs can be used (individually or together) to help first responders and emergency planners access and manage crucial chemical property and emergency response information for hazardous chemical releases.  The CAMEO programs are developed jointly by EPAs Office of Emergency Management and NOAAs Office of Response and Restoration.

CHIPS :: Chemical Hazard Information Profiles (CHIPS) summarize readily available information on health and environmental effects and exposure relating to a specific chemical substance.  The CHIPS database contains information about chemical substances that have been referenced in these profiles.  The EPA Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics (OPPT) prepared CHIPs summaries from 1978 to 1990.  Risk Management One Screening (RM1), which is part of the Existing Chemicals Program currently managed by OPPT, has superseded these profiles.

CORR :: The CORR database contains information on chemical substances, categories, and mixtures that are regulated under specific sections of the  Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), or section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA). These chemical substances have been the subject of proposed or final rules issued by  the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics (OPPT) in the Federal Register (FR).  Certain TSCA 5(e) consent order chemicals are also included.  The CORR database consists of two parts, a list of chemicals regulated by certain sections of TSCA and EPCRA, and a list of FR citations relevant to the specific regulation of chemical substances. The information on CORR contained in the SRS was derived from the CORR database dated September 30, 2001.

StringWithMarkup.String: Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Information System - 3

nodes.description: CERCLIS3 :: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Information System (CERCLIS) is an automated inventory of abandoned, inactive, or uncontrolled hazardous waste sites regulated under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA).  The system also tracks areas where there has been a hazardous substance release that may require evaluation or cleanup by the Superfund program.  CERCLIS3 is used to record information about all aspects of hazardous waste sites from initial discovery to listing on the National Priorities List (NPL).  The CERCLIS3 data elements registered in the EDR are only a subset of the CERCLIS3 system data elements.  The investment is a legacy system and is nearing the end of its projected life.  EPA will begin planning for the next generation of the system as part of its review of the Superfund program already committed to and the continued development of the Agency's and Superfund's Enterprise Architecture.  At that time EPA will evaluate the alternatives available using many tools, including benefit/cost analysis. These efforts will be reported through the CPIC process and a benefit/cost analysis will include an evaluation of outsourcing, COTS, and other appropriate alternatives.

CLPSS :: CLPSS provides the means to individually identify, track, monitor, and oversee the quality of each analysis performed on Superfund samples from the point of collection through final data reporting and payment.
ECOTOX :: Comprehensive database providing adverse effects of single chemical stressors to ecologically relevent aquatic and terrestrial species.

ERNS :: ERNS is a database used to store information on notifications of oil discharges and hazardous substances releases. The ERNS program is a cooperative data sharing effort encompassing the National Response Center (NRC), operated by the US Coast Guard, EPA HQ and EPA regional offices.  ERNS data is used to analyze release notifications, track EPA responses and compliance to environmental laws, support emergency planning efforts, and assist decision-makers in developing spill prevention programs.

EIS :: The purpose of the NEI Storage and Distribution system is:

1)	to provide storage for historical, current, and projected future Criteria and Hazardous Air Pollutant (CAP and HAP) emission inventories; and,

2)	to provide OAQPS and other EPA offices access to historical, current, and projected future CAP and HAP emission inventories.



Both of these projects are in support of national level regulatory programs under the Clean Air Act.   



For CAPs, this work is required by to implement Section 109, 110 of the Clean Air Act and to achieve deadlines as required by the Act for ozone and particulate matter National Ambient Air Quality Standards.  For HAPs, this work is required by Section 112 of the Clean Air Act.  This work provides computational resources for using the Abest science@ for supporting regulations and meeting environmental goals, as required by Congress.



The NEI Oracle databases will be used to store both CAP and HAP emissions data.  There will be no confidential business information received into the data bases located in the EMAD UNIX system.  Once loaded into the EMAD UNIX system, the data are processed before being installed into the appropriate Oracle databases.  The Oracle databases will be managed by a contractor from Lockheed-Martin, including applying security measures to the data, its use and integrity. 



The National Emission inventory ON the internet (NEON) cold fusion application is a web-based query and reporting tool for the NEI providing READ ONLY access to the NEI for EPA Headquarter and Regional Offices.  The NEON distribution system is located on Colossus, an NT server owned by the Information Transfer and Program Integration Division (ITPID).  The NEI Application Manager (EPA) is the NEON Application administrator.  The NEON cold fusion application will be managed by a PES/MACTEC contractor.

EIMS :: The Environmental Information Management System (EIMS) provides EPA with the capability to store and retrieve environmental data resources that have been created or otherwise used by the agency.  Planning for this system began in 1995.  It was subsequently developed and initially implemented in 1997.  Since that time, EIMS stabilized as a system and continued to evolve through a series of maintenance updates that provided orthogonal views into EIMS's information to better serve its partners' needs across the agency and Federal Government.   It is currently considered to be in a "steady state" phase of ongoing Operations and Maintenance in the EPA's CPIC process.  Since EIMS is moving into the operations and maintenance steady state in FY 2005, a comprehensive post implementation review (PIR) analysis will be completed in FY 2006 which will include an E-Gov strategy review.  In addition, this review will include compliance with the EPA modernization blue print.  



EIMS provides a metadata repository of information about EPA projects, data sets, databases, models, and documents used or created during various environmental projects. Using common web browser software, users may conduct searches for specific data, locate descriptive information about environmental project resources, and download (or be connected to) the resulting data, models, and/or other documents for local usage.

ERAMS :: The Environmental Radiation Ambient Monitoring System (ERAMS) is a national network of monitoring stations that regularly collect air, precipitation, drinking water, and milk samples for analysis of radioactivity. The ERAMS network, which has stations in each State, has been used to track environmental releases of radioactivity from nuclear weapons tests and nuclear accidents. Future uses of this network might include monitoring waste disposal and radioactive cleanup sites. ERAMS also documents the status and trends of environmental radioactivity; these data are published by National Air and Radiation Environmental Laboratory (NAREL) in a quarterly report entitled Environmental Radiation Data. Previously this was a paper only publication, but it is now being published online as well.

GLENDA :: The Great Lakes Environmental Database (GLENDA) is an Oracle database designed to store data from four subject areas: project/organization (such as project metadata, organizations and persons involved in the project along with their mailing addresses, electronic addresses, and telephone numbers), station/location (such as metadata about sampling stations, latitude and longitude of sampling points or areas, the geopositioning and geographic metadata), field monitoring activities (such as visits to stations for monitoring, observations or measurements taken during sampling or in the lab and metadata about field sampling or lab activities), and results (such as analytical results, analytes, units of measure, correction factors, quality assurance codes and flags, and any remarks on laboratory analyses).

GCES :: The Green Chemistry Expert System (GCES) is a tool currently under development by the U.S. EPA, which will allow users to build a green chemical process, design a green chemical, or survey the field of green chemistry. Its primary purpose is to guide users in the design of chemical products and processes that reduce or eliminate the use or generation of hazardous substances. This new approach to pollution prevention is the central focus of EPA`s Green Chemistry Program. The GCES will be a primary source of linear structural formulas in the CRS.

StringWithMarkup.String: High Production Volume Challenge Program / Voluntary Childrens Chemical Evaluation Program Information System

nodes.description: HPVIS :: The HPVIS/VCCEP Information System will allow EPA to receive and manage documents and data generated for the High Production Volume (HPV) Initiative, the Voluntary Children's Chemical Evaluation Program (VCCEP), and other EPA initiatives. It will also track the status of submitters` commitments, test plans, and other milestones.  HPVIS is a critical component of the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics` ability to fulfill its mandate under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).   OPPT has succeeded in meeting the information needs of TSCA for many years, primarily by managing the data flow through incremental, evolutionary improvements in information management.  Over time, however, this approach has led to an information processing architecture characterized by stand-alone, stovepipe systems using non-standard Agency software which incorporates differing business processes or incomplete/fragmented business processes.

ICIS-Air manages stationary source air program compliance and enforcement information. The data stored in ICIS-Air are primarily collected by State and local agencies and submitted to ICIS-Air as required by rule. The data stored in ICIS-Air are needed by EPA and state/local air agencies to carry out air program compliance management.

ICIS :: A single system to support the integrated business needs of the National Enforcement and Compliance program and to support the unique needs of the NPDES water program and other programs. A modernized information system that improves data sharing with States and other partners.

IRIS :: The Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) is an electronic data base maintained by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) that contains information on human health effects that may result from exposure to various chemicals in the environment.  IRIS was developed by EPA to provide toxicological information for use in risk assessments, decision-making, and to support other regulatory  activities.  The heart of the IRIS system is its collection of computer files covering individual chemicals. These files contain descriptive and quantitative information on over five hundred chemicals, including oral reference doses (RfD) and inhalation reference concentrations (RfC) for chronic noncarcinogenic health effects, and oral slope factors, oral and inhalation units risks for carcinogenic effects. IRIS also provides various related background and reference documents explaining the rationales and methods used to develop the list of chemicals.  The system is intended for those without extensive training in toxicology, but with some knowledge of health sciences.

MTL96 :: The Master Testing List (MTL) is compiled by the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics (OPPT) as part of the Existing Chemicals Program to help establish the chemical testing agenda for the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).  The MTL is used by OPPT to identify and focus resources on priority testing needs, to share this information with the public and industry, and to encourage testing initiatives by industry.  The MTL includes all active chemicals in the Screening Information Data Set program (SIDS), an international voluntary information sharing and testing program developed under the aegis of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

StringWithMarkup.String: Office of Pesticide Programs Information Network

nodes.description: OPPIN :: The Office of Pesticide Programs has migrated all of its major data systems including regulatory and scientific data, workflow tracking and electronic document management into one integrated system, the Office of Pesticide Programs Information Network (OPPIN).  OPPIN consolidates information now stored on the mainframe, the OPP LAN, on stand alone computers and in paper copy.

PCS :: The Permit Compliance System is an EPA national database used to track National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) surface water permits issued under the Clean Water Act. It provides information about permit issuance, permit limits, monitoring data, and other data pertaining to wastewater treatment facilities regulated under NPDES.  PCS supports the NPDES program at the state, regional, and national levels.

PEPS :: The EPA Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics (OPPT) prepared Production/Exposure Profiles (PEPS) from 1978 to 1986.  The PEPS database contains information about chemical substances that have been referenced in these profiles.

RMP*Info :: Under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) facilities that handle, manufacture, use, or store certain toxic and flammable substances are required to have in place a risk management program and submit to EPA a summary of that program in the form of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  RMP*Info is one component of the System for Risk Management Plans (SRMP), developed by EPA to facilitate the electronic submission and retrieval of RMPs.  RMP*Info contains the risk management plans reported by facilities that are subject to CAA 112(r).

SPECIATE is EPA's repository of Total Organic Compound (TOC) and Particulate Matter (PM) speciated profiles for a variety of sources for use in source apportionment studies. This release of SPECIATE no longer contains profiles assigned to SCC's. Instead, searching for profiles by keyword has been improved and of course the user can still browse through the profiles. Some additional improvements have been made to the interface, and some minor bugs associated with the export feature have been fixed. No new profiles have been added to SPECIATE since the previous release in October, 1999.

StringWithMarkup.String: Safe Drinking Water Information System in Envirofacts

nodes.description: SDWIS-Enviro :: The Safe Drinking Water Information System (SDWIS) in Envirofacts contains an extract of the national SDWIS database. It contains information about public water systems and their violations of EPA`s drinking water regulations. These statutes and accompanying regulations establish maximum contaminant levels, treatment techniques, and monitoring and reporting requirements to ensure that water provided to customers is safe for human consumption. Regulated substances include chemicals, microorganisms, and other properties such as color, odor, and turbidity.

StringWithMarkup.String: Section 319 Grants Reporting and Tracking System

nodes.description: GRTS :: The Section 319 Grants Reporting and Tracking System (GRTS) is the main reporting vehicle for the Section 319 program. GRTS enables EPA and States to describe the progress they have made in implementing the national Nonpoint Source (NPS) Pollution program. GRTS electronically tracks projects and activities funded with CWA Section 319(h) funds.

StringWithMarkup.String: Storage and Retrieval for Water Quality Data

nodes.description: STORET :: STORET/WQX defines the methods and the data systems by which EPA compiles monitoring data (typically water quality data, but not exclusively water quality data) that are collected by a number of entities.  Those entities could be states, tribes, volunteer monitoring groups, or EPA.  The purpose of the compilation of this data is to provide a seamless collection of monitoring data that is not restricted by jurisdictional boundaries.  These data also provide the foundation for a number of water quality decisions, whether they be the setting of water quality standards, 305(b) assessment conclusions, 303(d) listings, the setting of Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs), or permit renewals.  This system also provides a means of supporting EPA generated reports (i.e. the Wadeable Streams Report, or the Katrina Emergency Response).  As of May 2006, the STORET Warehouse has reports of 42 million monitoring results representing visits to 250,000 stations. For further information, visit the STORET web site at http://www.epa.gov/storet.

Sub Haz Prof :: Substitute Hazard Profiles (Sub Haz Prof) summarize readily available information on health and environmental effects relating to a specific chemical.  The Sub Haz Prof database contains information about chemical substances that have been referenced in these profiles.  The EPA Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics (OPPT) prepared the Sub Haz Prof summaries from 1985 to 1990.  Risk Management Two Scoping (RM2), which is part of the Existing Chemicals Program currently managed by OPPT, has superseded these profiles.
SEMS :: Superfund Enterprise Management System

StringWithMarkup.String: Toxic Substances Control Act Test Submissions

nodes.description: TSCATS :: TSCATS (Toxic Substances Control Act Test Submissions):  TSCATS tracks the submissions of health and safety data submitted to the EPA either as required or voluntarily under certain sections of TSCA:  (1) as required by promulgated TSCA section 4 Rules or Enforceable Consent Agreements (ECA), promulgated section 8(d) rules, automatic 8(d) reporting requirements as a result of designations or recommendations made by the TSCA Inter-Agency Testing Committee (ITC), and notices of substantial risk under TSCA section 8(e); and (2) voluntarily as FYI (For Your Information) and Inter-Agency Testing Commission (ITC) submissions. TSCATS tracks all such submissions (whether or not they contain claims of confidentiality or privacy), but contains only non-confidential tracking information on these submissions.

TRIPS :: The TRI Program is responsible for implementing the Agency s obligations under the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986 to annually collect toxic chemical release information from certain facilities and provide the public with access to this information through electronic and other means.   In order to meet this statutory obligation, the TRI Program has developed and operates the Toxics Release Inventory System (TRIS) and its associated Reporting Center.  TRIS is the information system that EPA uses to manage the collection, processing, storage and public dissemination of the approximately 120,000 TRI forms that facilities submit each year.  TRIS is used by the EPCRA Reporting Center to do all the work of receiving, processing, and disseminating the TRI submissions.

StringWithMarkup.String: United States High Production Volume Challenge Program List

nodes.description: HPVC List :: The United States High Production Volume (USHPV) database contains information about chemicals that are included in the High Production Volume (HPV) Challenge Program.  Chemicals considered to be HPV are those that are manufactured in or imported into the United States in amounts equal to or greater than one million pounds per year.  The goal of the HPV Challenge Program is to complete baseline testing on HPV chemicals by the year 2004.  The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is challenging the chemical industry to undertake testing on HPV chemicals voluntarily. However, EPA will mandate testing of all HPV chemicals by law under the testing authority of Section 4 of the Toxic Substance Control Act (TSCA).

WQX :: STORET/WQX defines the methods and the data systems by which EPA compiles monitoring

 data (typically water quality data, but not exclusively water quality data) that are

 collected by a number of entities.  Those entities could be states, tribes, volunteer

 monitoring groups, or EPA.  The purpose of the compilation of this data is to provide

 a seamless collection of monitoring data that is not restricted by jurisdictional

 boundaries.  These data also provide the foundation for a number of water

 quality decisions, whether they be the setting of water quality standards,

 305(b) assessment conclusions, 303(d) listings, the setting of Total Maximum Daily Loads

 (TMDLs), or permit renewals.  This system also provides a means of supporting EPA

 generated reports (i.e. the Wadeable Streams Report, or the Katrina Emergency Response).

 As of May 2006, the STORET Warehouse has reports of 42 million monitoring results

 representing visits to 250,000 stations. For further information, visit

 the STORET web site at http://www.epa.gov/storet.
List type: External List
ATF :: ATF-18 U.S.C841(c)

StringWithMarkup.String: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry

nodes.description: ATSDR :: The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) database contains information about chemical substances that are considered to be toxicological profile candidates.  The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA or Superfund), as amended by the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (SARA) requires ATSDR and EPA to maintain a Priority List of Hazardous Substances.  Each substance on the priority list is a candidate to become the subject of a toxicological profile prepared by ATSDR with the subsequent identification of priority data for that substance.  The ATSDR database includes chemicals from that priority list.

ANSI :: The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) facilitates the development of American National Standards (ANS) by accrediting the procedures of standards developing organizations (SDOs). These groups work cooperatively to develop voluntary national consensus standards. Accreditation by ANSI signifies that the procedures used by the standards body in connection with the development of American National Standards meet the Institutes essential requirements for openness, balance, consensus and due process.

ANSI has served in its capacity as administrator and coordinator of the United States private sector voluntary standardization system for more than 90 years. Founded in 1918 by five engineering societies and three government agencies, the Institute remains a private, nonprofit membership organization supported by a diverse constituency of private and public sector organizations.

ChemIDplus :: ChemIDplus is a database that contains about 350,000 chemical records.  Access to the database is provided by Specialized Information Services (SIS) of the U.S. National Library of Medicine (NLM).  Chemical names, including one or more systematic names, Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) Registry Numbers, molecular formulas, molecular structures (for about 56,000 chemicals), and locator links to other chemical databases are available through this database.

CA Index :: The Chemical Abstracts Services (CAS) Registry File is a chemical structure and dictionary database containing unique records for chemical substances that have been published. All substance records are assigned a unique CAS Registry Number and a Chemical Abstracts (CA) index name.  The records may also contain additional information, such as other names, molecular formulas, and structure diagrams related to the specific substance.  The CA Index name is used as the name source in CRS when an 8th or 9th CI name is not available.

CAS Registry :: The CAS Registry database is the original supplier and final authority for CAS Registry Numbers (CASRNs or CAS Numbers). The Registry is updated daily. SRS uses this information resource to verify and identify former CAS Registry Numbers. There are no substance names associated with the CAS Registry acronym in SRS.  Names obtained from Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) are associated with the acronym for the specific Collective Index nomenclature rules that were used to assign the systematic name of the substance.

StringWithMarkup.String: Chemical Abstracts Service, 8th Collective Index Nomenclature

nodes.description: CAS-8CI :: Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) monitors, indexes, and abstracts chemical literature and patents.  CAS has developed a systematic nomenclature standard to describe the substances found in literature and patents.  The 8th Collective Index nomenclature system was developed and used from 1967 to 1971.

StringWithMarkup.String: Chemical Abstracts Service, 9th Collective Index Nomenclature

nodes.description: CAS-9CI :: Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) monitors, indexes, and abstracts chemical literature and patents.  CAS has developed a systematic nomenclature standard to describe the substances found in literature and patents.  Use of the 9th Collective Index (9CI) nomenclature system began in 1972.  The preferred Chemical Abstracts index names for chemical substances, with minor changes and extensions, continue to be those developed using the 9CI rules.

CFATS :: Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standards - Chemicals of Interest

Federal Register / Vol. 72, No. 223 / Tuesday, November 20, 2007

ChemIDStd :: The Chemical Identification Data Standard was developed by a Chemical Data Standard Work Group comprised of representatives from across U.S. EPA programs. The consensus standard defines what information is required to identify a chemical substance and how that information should be recorded.  The Chemical Identification Data Standard provides for the use of 4 specific identifiers for chemical substances in the Substance Registry System: the Chemical Abstracts Service Registry Number (CASRN) - the unique number assigned by Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) to a chemical substance; the Chemical Substance Systematic Name - the name assigned to a chemical substance that describes it in terms of its molecular composition; the EPA Chemical Internal Tracking Number - the unique record number assigned to all chemical substances and chemical groupings for internal tracking within EPA systems; and the EPA Chemical Registry Name - the name EPA has selected as the name to be commonly used by EPA in referring to a chemical substance.

CUS86 :: The Chemical Update System (CUS) contains information that must be reported by chemical manufacturers and importers every four years as a partial update to the chemical inventory which is maintained under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).  CUS86 contains information about all non-confidential chemicals that are in the 1986 Chemical Update System for which only non-CBI production volume aggregates are available.

CUS90 :: The Chemical Update System (CUS) contains information that must be reported by chemical manufacturers and importers every four years as a partial update to the chemical inventory which is maintained under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).  CUS90 contains information about all non-confidential chemicals that are in the 1990 Chemical Update System for which only non-CBI production volume aggregates are available.

CUS94 :: The Chemical Update System (CUS) contains information that must be reported by chemical manufacturers and importers every four years as a partial update to the chemical inventory which is maintained under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA).  CUS94 contains information about all chemicals for which the identity has not been claimed Confidential Business Information (CBI) in the 1994 Chemical Update System, including chemicals for which both CBI and non-CBI production volume aggregates are available.

CUS98 :: The Chemical Update System (CUS) contains information about certain chemical substances included on the TSCA Chemical Substances Inventory, maintained under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), as a partial update to the Inventory.  The rule requires manufacturers and importers of certain chemical substances included on the inventory to report current data on the production volume, plant site, and site-limited status of these substances.  CUS98 contains a list of all chemicals for which the identity has not been claimed Confidential Business Information (CBI) in the 1998 reporting period from August 25, 1998 to January 31, 1999.  This reporting period is applicable to 1998 reporting only.  Reporting under the Inventory Update Rule (40 CFR 710) takes place at four-year intervals which began in 1986.

CUS02 :: The Chemical Update System (CUS) contains information about certain chemical substances included on the TSCA Chemical Substances Inventory, maintained under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA), as a partial update to the Inventory. The rule requires manufacturers and importers of certain chemical substances included on the inventory to report current data on the production volume, plant site, and site-limited status of these substances. CUS02 contains a list of all chemicals for which the identity has not been claimed Confidential Business Information (CBI) in the 2002 reporting period from August 26, 2002 to December 23, 2002. Reporting under the Inventory Update Rule (40 CFR part 710) takes place at four-year intervals which began in 1986.

StringWithMarkup.String: Dictionary of Chemical Names and Synonyms

nodes.description: DCNS :: The Dictionary of Chemical Names and Synonyms (DCNS) provides information about the chemical nomenclature, formula, molecular weight, structure, and CAS Registry Number of over 20,000 chemicals that are commonly referenced by chemical investigators.   Two databases developed for the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) served as the base list for this dictionary, i.e.,  the Toxic Substances Control Act Test Submisssions (TSCATS) and the Environmental Fate Data Base (EFDB).  Other databases were used to ensure that all significant chemicals would be included.

StringWithMarkup.String: Food and Drug Administration Substance Registry

nodes.description: FDA :: The primary goal of the FDA/USP Substance Registration System (SRS) is to unambiguously define all substances present in regulated products. Once a substance has been defined, the SRS assigns a strong identifier that is permanently associated with the substance. SRS is intended to be a general use resource and data presented here has been collected from public information sources. Inclusion of a substance in this database does not indicate that it is currently under review by the FDA or a substance in any FDA regulated product

GLFMP :: The Great Lakes Fish Contaminant Monitoring Program (GLFMP), is a program begun in 1980 as a cooperative effort by USEPA, U.S. Food and Drug Administration (no longer participating), U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (now the Biological Resources Division of U.S. Geological Survey), and the eight Great Lakes States, to monitor and better define the fish contaminant problem in the Great Lakes. The GLFMP has served as a model for interagency cooperation and coordination.

StringWithMarkup.String: Hazard Assessment of the Organophosphates,  July 7, 1998.

nodes.description: OP RPT 0798 :: Hazard Assessment of the Organophosphates is a draft report that was completed July 7, 1998, by the Hazard Identification Assessment Review Committee (HIARC), Health Effects Division, Office of Pesticide Programs, USEPA. The report outlines the neurotoxic, developmental, and reproductive toxic potential of 40 organophosphates that were evaluated by HIARC from September 1997 to May 1998.

HSDB :: Hazardous Substance Data Bank (HSDB) is a factual, non-bibliographic data bank focusing upon the toxicology of potentially hazardous chemicals including emergency handling procedures, environmental fate, human exposure, industrial hygiene, and regulatory requirements.  HSDB is fully peer reviewed by the Scientific Review Panel (SRP), a committee of subject matter experts.  HSDB is being built, maintained, reviewed, and updated by the National Library of Medicine (NLM).

IADN :: The Integrated Atmospheric Deposition Network (IADN) was established by the United States and Canada for conducting air and precipitation monitoring in the Great Lakes Basin, cooperating to implement the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement. The IADN has been in operation since 1990 under the guidance of an implementation plan signed in that year. Since 1999 the program is comprised of the following three agencies: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, mandated under Section 112(m) of the Clean Air Acts Amendments of 1990; Environment Canada`s (EC) Meteorological Service of Canada; and EC`s Ecosystem Health Division of Ontario Region (EHD).

StringWithMarkup.String: International Agency for Research on Cancer

nodes.description: IARC :: The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) is part of the World Health Organization. Its mission is to coordinate and conduct research on the causes of human cancer, the mechanisms of carcinogenesis, and to develop scientific strategies for cancer control. The IARC is involved in both epidemiological and laboratory research and disseminates scientific information through publications, meetings, courses, and fellowships.  Chemical substances that are identified with CAS Registry Numbers and that exist in the EPA Chemical Registry System are linked to monographs that provide information about hazards evaluated to date, according to the type of hazard posed and to the type of exposure.

ISO :: ISO (International Organization for Standardization) is the world's largest developer and publisher of International Standards.



ISO is a network of the national standards institutes of 157 countries, one member per country, with a Central Secretariat in Geneva, Switzerland, that coordinates the system. 



ISO is a non-governmental organization that forms a bridge between the public and private sectors. On the one hand, many of its member institutes are part of the governmental structure of their countries, or are mandated by their government. On the other hand, other members have their roots uniquely in the private sector, having been set up by national partnerships of industry associations. 



Therefore, ISO enables a consensus to be reached on solutions that meet both the requirements of business and the broader needs of society.

ITER :: ITER contains data in support of human health risk assessments. It is compiled by Toxicology Excellence for Risk Assessment (TERA) and contains over 650 chemical records with key data from the Agency for Toxic Substances & Disease Registry (ATSDR), Health Canada, National Institute of Public Health & the Environment (RIVM) - The Netherlands, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) (in progress), NSF International, and independent parties whose risk values have undergone peer review. ITER provides a comparison of international risk assessment information in a side-by-side format and explains differences in risk values derived by different organizations. ITER data, focusing on hazard identification and dose-response assessment, is extracted from each agencys assessment and contains links to the source documentation. Among the key data provided in ITER are ATSDRs minimal risk levels; Health Canadas tolerable intakes/concentrations and tumorigenic doses/concentrations; EPAs carcinogen classifications, unit risks, slope factors, oral reference doses, and inhalation reference concentrations; RIVMs maximum permissible risk levels; NSF International's reference doses and carcinogen risk levels, IARC's cancer classifications, and noncancer and/or cancer risk values (that have undergone peer review) derived by independent parties.

StringWithMarkup.String: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry

nodes.description: IUPAC :: IUPAC is an international non-governmental organization established in 1919 devoted to the advancement of chemistry. It has as its members national chemistry societies. It is most well known as the recognized authority in developing standards for the naming of the chemical elements and their compounds, through its Interdivisional Committee on Nomenclature and Symbols (IUPAC nomenclature). It is a member of the International Council for Science (ICSU).

MTL :: Under Section 4 of the Toxic Substance Control Act (TSCA), EPA has the authority to require chemical manufacturers and processors to test existing chemicals if the chemical(s) may present an unreasonable risk of injury to human health, is produced in substantial quantities that could result in substantial environmental exposure, or the available data to evaluate the environmental impact of the chemical(s) are inadequate.  OPPT has been using the MTL since 1990 to establish its TSCA Existing Chemical Testing Program agenda. Under this program, OPPT works with members of the U.S. chemical industry to develop needed data via TSCA Section 4 Enforceable Consent Agreements (ECAs) and Voluntary Testing Agreements (VTAs). The MTL presents a consolidated listing of OPPT`s existing chemical testing priorities for 1996-1998 and contains of a list of over 500 individual chemicals and nearly 20 chemical categories.  The MTL presented in this database was derived from OPPT`s 1996 MTL.

Merck(11) :: The Merck Index 11th Edition is a multidisciplinary encyclopedia that contains descriptions of important chemicals, drugs, biological, agricultural, and natural products. It also contains chemical names, trivial and generic names, trade names and their associated companies, Chemical Abstracts Service Registry Numbers, molecular formulas and weights, therapeutic and commercial uses, structure diagrams, and bibliographic citations to the scientific and patent literature, as well as the referenced patents and other source information.  Derivative information and numeric data for physical and toxicity properties are also included.

Merck(12) :: The Merck Index 12th Edition is a multidisciplinary encyclopedia that contains  more than 10,000 monographs describing a single substance or small group of related compounds.  It covers human and veterinary drugs, commercial and laboratory chemicals, biologicals, natural products, agricultural compounds, and environmentally significant compounds.  It contains chemical names, trivial and generic names, trade names and their associated companies, Chemical Abstracts Service Registry Numbers, molecular formulas and weights, therapeutic and commercial uses, structures diagrams, and bibliographic citations to the scientific and patent literature, as well as the referenced patents and other source information.  Derivative information and numeric data for physical and toxicity properties are also included.  The information is available in printed form and on CD with searching software.

StringWithMarkup.String: National Toxicology Program Chemical Health and Safety Data

nodes.description: NTP Chemical Repository :: The National Toxicology Program (NTP) was established in 1978 to coordinate toxicology research and testing activities within the National Institutes of Health/National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIH/NIEHS).  The NTP Chemical Repository provides links to nearly 2000 chemical health and safety data sheets for chemicals existing in the Chemical Registry System (CRS). These health and safety data sheets provide detailed information and data for each chemical, including CASRN number, chemical and structural formula, synonyms, physical chemical data, and toxicological and regulatory data.  Document linkages in the CRS were obtained from the NTP webpage in March 2001.

NTP Studies :: The National Toxicology Program (NTP) was established in 1978 to coordinate toxicology research and testing activities within the National Institutes of Health/National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIH/NIEHS).  The NTP is involved with relevant toxicology activities of the NIH/NIEHS, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the National Cancer Institute (NCI).  The NTP is a leading authority on the design, conduct, and interpretation of animal assays for toxicity and carcinogenicity.  This source provides links to NTP study abstracts (available as of March 2001) for chemicals existing in the Chemical Registry System (CRS), including short-term and long-term carcinogenicity, immunotoxicity, reproductive toxicity, and teratology studies.

NWIS :: The United States Geological Survey (USGS) has collected water-resources data at approximately 1.5 million sites in all 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands

StringWithMarkup.String: New Jersey Right to Know Hazardous Substances Fact Sheets

nodes.description: NJ-RTK-HS :: The New Jersey Department of Health provides Hazardous Substance Fact Sheets (HSFS) on nearly 1200 hazardous chemicals. Each HSFS details health and safety information about a hazardous chemical, including workplace exposure routes and limits, health hazards (acute and chronic), storage and handling procedures, and information on personal protection equipment.  Physical data such as vapor pressure, flash point, etc. are also given for each chemical.  The CRS contains information only about those chemicals from this source that are of interest to EPA.  A complete listing of HSFSs, including Spanish translations of the HSFS, are available at the home webpage.
OSHA, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals standard (29 CFR 1910.119)

POPs :: Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) are chemical substances that persist in the environment, bioaccumulate through the food web, and pose a risk of causing adverse effects to human health and the environment. With the evidence of long-range transport of these substances to regions where they have never been used or produced and the consequent threats they pose to the environment of the whole globe, the international community has called for urgent global actions to reduce and eliminate releases of these chemicals.

PIC-DGD :: The growth of world trade in chemicals has led to increasing concerns about the health and environmental risks associated with the importation and use of hazardous chemicals.  In response to these concerns, the Rotterdam Convention was adopted on the Prior Informed Consent (PIC) Procedures for Certain Hazardous Chemicals and Pesticides in International Trade, under the auspices of United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations.  PIC procedures help participating countries learn more about potentially hazardous chemicals that may be imported and provides detailed information on specific chemicals and pesticides in the form of Decision Guidance Document (DGDs), including bans or restrictions, toxicity, proper handling, labeling, measures to reduce exposure, and international hazard classifications.  This source provides links to over 50 DGDs for chemicals existing in the  Chemical Registry System (CRS) as of February 2001.

STN :: Scientific and Technology Network (STN) International is a fee-based, web accessible information network providing access to more than 200 databases from the world`s leading scientific organizations. STN is a service operated jointly by Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) in North America, Japan Science and Technology Corporation in Asia, and FIZ-Karlsruhe in Germany. STN Easy is interfaced with the CAS chemical database, CAplus. SRS uses this information resource to verify CAS Registry Numbers and substance names. There are no substance names associated with the STN acronym in SRS.

StringWithMarkup.String: Screening Information Data Set-High Production Volume Chemicals

nodes.description: SIDS :: Since 1988, the member nations of the International Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) have undertaken a systematic investigation of the potential risks to human health and the environment associated with high production volume (HPV) chemicals.   The set of chemical substances evaluated has been termed the Screening Information Data Set (SIDS).  The OECD uses the information contained in the SIDS to establish further testing and information gathering requirements.   The CRS provides links to nearly 75 chemicals that have been evaluated under this program.  Some  SIDS linkages retrieve reports from the International Uniform Chemicals Information Database (IUCLID).
List type: Statute/Regulation

CWA Priority :: The Clean Water Act (CWA) Priority Pollutant list, from the 40CFR423 Appendix A, is a list of 126 chemical substances to be given priority consideration in the development of effluent limitations guidelines pursuant to the Clean Water Act (CWA) 304(b).  The list of 126 analytes was developed by EPA and agreed to in negotiations with the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC).  Originally, there were 129 compounds on the list, however, three substances were delisted in 1981.  The CAS Registry Numbers for the substances were not included in the CFR reference.
2012 CDR Partial Exempt

This list contains chemicals that are fully exempt from reporting under 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR), as long as they are not also found in certain TSCA actions.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers, and is based upon the status of a chemical on June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 CDR.

This list contains chemicals that are partially exempt from reporting under 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR), as long as they are not also found in certain TSCA actions.  Manufacturers (including importers) of partially exempt chemicals are not required to report processing and use information, but are required to report basic identity and manufacturing information.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers, if applicable, and is based upon the status of a chemical on June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 CDR.

This list contains chemicals that are found in TSCA section 4 Enforceable Consent Agreements (ECA), minus any of those chemicals that have a sunset date that occured before June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reportign period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a TSCA section 4 ECA -- on June 1, 2016. This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers, if applicable.

This list contains chemicals that are found in proposed and final TSCA section 4 test rules, minus any of those chemicals that have a sunset date that occurred before June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a TSCA section 4 test rule -- on June 1, 2016.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers, if applicable.

This list contains chemicals that are found in proposed and final significant new use rules (SNURs) under TSCA section 5(a) as of June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  SNURs provide EPA with an opportunity to review a use before it occurs and, if necessary, manage risk. The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a regulation such as a TSCA section 5(a) SNUR -- on June 1, 2016.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers.

This list contains chemicals that are found in TSCA section 5(e) consent orders as of June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  When reviewing a pre-manufacture notice (PMN) for a new chemical, EPA can determine that use under certain conditions and with agreed precautions would not pose an unreasonable risk, but that use under other conditions may pose an unreasonable risk. Depending on the circumstances, EPA may issue an order under TSCA section 5(e) to prohibit or limit activities associated with the chemical, such as exposure or release mitigation, testing, labeling and hazard communication, and recordkeeping. The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a regulation such as a TSCA section 5(e) consent order -- on June 1, 2016.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers.

This list contains chemicals that are found in TSCA section 5(f) rules as of June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  If EPA determines that the manufacturing, processing, distribution in commerce, or disposal of a chemical that is the subject of a pre-manufacture notice (PMN) or significant new use notice (SNUN) requirements presents or will present an unreasonable risk before a TSCA section 6 rule can be promulgated, under TSCA section 5(f), EPA may (1) limit the amount or impose other restrictions on the chemical via an immediately effective proposed rule, or (2) prohibit the manufacturing, processing or distribution in commerce of the chemical by issuing a proposed order or applying to a U.S. District Court for an injunction.  The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a regulation such a TSCA section 5(f) rule -- on June 1, 2016. This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers, if applicable.

This list contains chemicals that are found in TSCA section 6 rules as of June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  EPA may issue a TSCA section 6 rule if it determines that one or more activities involving a substance/mixture presents or will present an unreasonable risk of injury to health or the environment. The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a regulation such as a TSCA section 6 rule -- on June 1, 2016.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers, if applicable.

This list contains chemicals that are found on the TSCA Inventory as of June 1, 2016, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2016 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR).  TSCA requires EPA to compile, keep current, and publish a list of each chemical that is manufactured (including imported) or processed in the U.S. for uses under TSCA. Companies that manufacture (including import) chemicals at certain volumes in the U.S. must report to EPA every four years through its CDR, and reporting requirements for the 2016 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical in terms of being subject to certain regulations on June 1, 2016.  This list contains CASRNs and accession numbers.

This list contains CASRNs that are fully exempt from reporting under 2020 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR), as long as they are not also found in certain TSCA actions. Reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical in terms of being subject to certain regulations on June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 CDR. Be sure to search SRS’ accession number webpage to find accession numbers associated with this list.

This list contains chemicals that are partially exempt from reporting under 2020 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR), as long as they are not also found in certain TSCA actions. Manufacturers (including importers) of partially exempt chemicals are not required to report processing and use information, but are required to report basic identity and manufacturing information. Reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical in terms of being subject to certain regulations on June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 CDR.

This list contains chemicals that are found in TSCA section 4 Enforceable Consent Agreements (ECA), minus any of those chemicals that have a sunset date that occurs before June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical -- e.g., if the chemical is included in a TSCA section 4 ECA -- on June 1, 2020.

This list contains CASRNs that are found in TSCA section 4 test orders as of June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). TSCA section 4 gives EPA the authority to require chemical manufacturers (including importers) and processors to test existing chemicals and report the results to EPA, and reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical in terms of being subject to certain regulations on June 1, 2020.

This list contains CASRNs that are found in proposed and final significant new use rules (SNURs) under TSCA section 5(a) as of June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). SNURs provide EPA with an opportunity to review a use before it occurs and, if necessary, manage risk. The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical – e.g., if the chemical is included in a regulation such as a TSCA section 5(a) SNUR – on June 1, 2020. Be sure to search SRS’ accession number webpage to find accession numbers associated with this list.

This list contains CASRNs that are found in TSCA section 5(e) consent orders as of June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). When reviewing a pre-manufacture notice (PMN) for a new chemical, EPA can determine that use under certain conditions and with agreed precautions would not pose an unreasonable risk, but that use under other conditions may pose an unreasonable risk. Depending on the circumstances, EPA may issue an order under TSCA section 5(e) to prohibit or limit activities associated with the chemical, such as exposure or release mitigation, testing, labeling and hazard communication, and recordkeeping. The CDR rule under TSCA requires manufacturers (including importers) to provide EPA with information on the production and use of chemicals in commerce at certain quantities every four years, and the reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical – e.g., if the chemical is included in a regulation such as a TSCA section 5(e) consent order – on June 1, 2020. Be sure to search SRS’ accession number webpage to find accession numbers associated with this list.

This list contains CASRN chemicals that are considered Active on the TSCA Inventory. TSCA requires EPA to compile, keep current, and publish a list of each chemical that is manufactured (including imported) or processed in the U.S. for uses under TSCA. Companies that manufacture (including import) chemicals at certain volumes in the U.S. must report to EPA every four years through its Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). Reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical in terms of being subject to certain regulations on June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 CDR.

This list contains CASRN chemicals that are considered Inactive on the TSCA Inventory. TSCA requires EPA to compile, keep current, and publish a list of each chemical that is manufactured (including imported) or processed in the U.S. for uses under TSCA. Companies that manufacture (including import) chemicals at certain volumes in the U.S. must report to EPA every four years through its Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). Reporting requirements for the 2020 CDR are based upon the status of a chemical in terms of being subject to certain regulations on June 1, 2020, which is the first day of the reporting period for the 2020 CDR. Be sure to search SRS’ accession number webpage to find accession numbers associated with this list.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 152.175: Pesticides classified for restricted use

nodes.description: Restricted Use Pesticides :: The  pesticide products containing the active ingredients specified here have been classified for restricted use and are limited to use by or under the direct supervision of a certified applicator.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 152.25: Exemptions for pesticides of a character not requiring FIFRA regulation - Active Ingredients

nodes.description: Exempted Minimum Risk Pesticide Products - Active Ingredients :: Active Ingredients Permitted in Exempted Minimum Risk Pesticide Products

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 152.25: Exemptions for pesticides of a character not requiring FIFRA regulation - Inert Ingredients

nodes.description: Exempted Minimum Risk Pesticide Products - Inert Ingredients :: Inert Ingredients Permitted in Exempted Minimum Risk Pesticide Products

Plant-incorporated Protectants - Exemptions :: The characteristics of plant-incorporated protectants such as their production and use in plants, their biological properties, and their ability to spread and increase in quantity in the environment distinguish them from traditional chemical pesticides. Therefore, plant-incorporated protectants are subject to some different regulatory requirements and procedures than traditional chemical pesticides. This subpart lists the tolerances and exemptions from the requirement of a tolerance for residues of plant-incorporated protectants in or on food commodities.

PRTI :: The PRTI Project converts pesticide tolerance information published in 40 CFR 180 into a relational database. The PRTI Substance List contains pesticide active ingredients, degradates, metabolites, and other substances referenced in tolerance expressions in the PRTI database.

Pesticide Tolerance Exemptions :: An exemption from a tolerance shall be granted when it appears that the total quantity of the pesticide chemical in or on all raw agricultural commodities for which it is useful under conditions of use currently prevailing or proposed will involve no hazard to the public health.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 257: Criteria for Classification of Solid Waste Disposal Facilities and Practices

nodes.description: Classification of Solid Waste Disposal Facilities and Practices :: Unless otherwise provided, the criteria in §§257.1 through 257.4 are adopted for determining which solid waste disposal facilities and practices pose a reasonable probability of adverse effects on health or the environment under sections 1008(a)(3) and 4004(a) of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (The Act). Unless otherwise provided, the criteria in §§257.5 through 257.30 are adopted for purposes of ensuring that non-municipal non-hazardous waste disposal units that receive very small quantity generator (VSQG) waste do not present risks to human health and the environment taking into account the practicable capability of such units in accordance with section 4010(c) of the Act. Unless otherwise provided, the criteria in §§257.50 through 257.107 are adopted for determining which CCR landfills and CCR surface impoundments pose a reasonable probability of adverse effects on health or the environment under sections 1008(a)(3) and 4004(a) of the Act.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 258: Criteria for Municipal Solid Waste Landfills

nodes.description: Criteria for Municipal Solid Waste Landfills :: The purpose of this part is to establish minimum national criteria under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA or the Act), as amended, for all municipal solid waste landfill (MSWLF) units and under the Clean Water Act, as amended, for municipal solid waste landfills that are used to dispose of sewage sludge. These minimum national criteria ensure the protection of human health and the environment.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 263: Standards Applicable to Transporters of Hazardous Waste

nodes.description: Standards Applicable to Transporters of Hazardous Waste :: These regulations establish standards which apply to persons transporting hazardous waste within the United States if the transportation requires a manifest under 40 CFR part 262.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 264 Appendix IX: Groundwater Monitoring List

nodes.description: RCRA: Appendix IX :: Appendix IX of 40 CFR Part 264 is a list of chemicals specific to groundwater monitoring at RCRA-permitted Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities (TSDFs) where such monitoring is required in the facility permit (typically for land-based hazardous waste management, such as a landfill).  Appendix IX of Part 264 represents a subset of the hazardous constituents found in 40 CFR Part 261, Appendix VIII, that are amenable to GW monitoring, and also contains some additional chemicals often addressed at CERCLA sites.  Appendix IX constituents which are not contained in Appendix VIII of Part 261, may be included as hazardous constituents into the Groundwater Protection Standard of a facility’s permit by the Regional Administrator using the omnibus authority of 40 CFR 270.32(b)(2) and RCRA section 3005(c)(3).”

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 264: Standards for Owners and Operators of Hazardous Waste Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities

nodes.description: Standards for Owners and Operators of Hazardous Waste Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities :: The purpose of this part is to establish minimum national standards which define the acceptable management of hazardous waste.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 265: Interim Status Standards for Owners and Operators of Hazardous Waste Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities

nodes.description: Interim Standards for Owners & Operators of Hazardous Waste Treatment Storage & Disposal Facilities :: The purpose of this part is to establish minimum national standards that define the acceptable management of hazardous waste during the period of interim status and until certification of final closure or, if the facility is subject to post-closure requirements, until post-closure responsibilities are fulfilled.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 266: Standards for the Management of Specific Hazardous Wastes and Specific Types of Hazardous Waste Management Facilities

nodes.description: Management of Specific Hazardous Wastes and Specific Types of Hazardous Waste Management Facilities :: Standards for the management of specific hazardous wastes and specific types of hazardous waste management facilities

Land Disposal Restrictions :: This part identifies hazardous wastes that are restricted from land disposal and defines those limited circumstances under which an otherwise prohibited waste may continue to be land disposed.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 273: Standards for Universal Waste Management

40 CFR 278: Criteria for the Management of Granular Mine Tailings (Chat) in Asphalt Concrete and Portland Cement Concrete in Transportation Construction Projects Funded in Whole or in Part by Federal Funds

nodes.description: Management of Mine Tailings (Chat) in Cement and Concrete in Transportation Construction Projects :: These requirements apply to chat from the Tri-State Mining District used in transportation construction projects carried out, in whole or in part, using Federal funds.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 279: Standards for the Management of Used Oil

nodes.description: Standards for the Management of Used Oil :: This section identifies those materials which are subject to regulation as used oil under this part. This section also identifies some materials that are not subject to regulation as used oil under this part, and indicates whether these materials may be subject to regulation as hazardous waste under parts 260 through 266, 268, 270, and 124 of this chapter.

StringWithMarkup.String: 40 CFR 503: Standards for the Use or Disposal of Sewage Sludge

nodes.description: Standards for the Use or Disposal of Sewage Sludge :: 40 CFR Part 503 (the Rule or Regulation), Standards for the Use or Disposal of Sewage Sludge, establishes standards, which consist of general requirements, pollutant limits, management practices, and operational standards, for the final use or disposal of sewage sludge generated during the treatment of domestic sewage in a treatment works. Standards are included for sewage sludge applied to the land, placed on a surface disposal site, or fired in a sewage sludge incinerator. Also included are pathogen and alternative vector attraction reduction requirements for sewage sludge applied to the land or placed on a surface disposal site.

TSCA 8C SARS :: Section 8(c) of TSCA establishes requirements for manufacturers and processors of chemical substances and mixtures to keep records of significant adverse reactions to health and the environment alleged to have been caused by the chemical substance or mixture and to permit inspection and submit copies of records as requested by EPA.  Allegations made under the TSCA 8(c) rule may be submitted without formal proof or evidence, but do not include allegations which are considered exempt under TSCA 8(c).  Records of alleged adverse reactions made by employees must be kept by the company for a period of 30 years, while other allegations (such as plant site neighbors) must be kept for a period of five years.
