TSCA 8A CAIR :: TSCA 8(a) Comprehensive Assessment Information Rule (CAIR) was a model rule that established a standard approach to gathering information on the manufacture, importation, and processing of substances.  It established uniform reporting and recordkeeping requirements that can be adapted to specific substances and a standardized reporting form.  This rule was intended to reduce duplicative reporting by industry and conserve EPA resources.  Amendments to this rule were expected to add chemicals to the rule, but not alter other parts of the regulatory text, unless otherwise stated. The CAIR requirements were rescinded in 1995. The chemicals listed for 8(a) CAIR in this database were derived from the Chemicals On Reporting Rules (CORR) database maintained by the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics.

StringWithMarkup.String: Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, And Liability Act Hazardous Substances

nodes.description: CERCLA :: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability (CERCLA) Act list of hazardous substances is a compilation of chemicals and mixtures identified primarily in Clean Water Act (CWA) Sections 311(b)(4), and 307(a), Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112, and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Section 3001.  Substances from the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) Section 7 and additional sources as designated by the Administrator may also be included.  Releases of substances on this list that are in excess of their reportable quantities must be reported to the National Response Center.  These chemicals are also subject to regulation under the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) Section 304.

CSAPR :: US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) finalized the Cross-State Air Pollution Rule (CSAPR) to address air pollution from upwind states that crosses state lines and affects air quality in downwind states. Sulfur dioxide (SO2) and oxides of nitrogen (NOX) emissions react in the atmosphere and contribute to the formation of fine particle (soot) pollution. NOX also contributes to ground-level ozone (smog) formation. These emissions and the soot and smog they form can affect air quality and public health locally, regionally, and in states hundreds of miles downwind.  

The CSAPR replaced the 2005 Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR), following the direction of a 2008 court decision that required EPA to issue a replacement regulation.  CSAPR implementation began on January 1, 2015.

HDDs/HDFs :: Section 4 of the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) requires that specified chemical substances be tested for the presence of halogenated dibenzo-para-dioxins (HDDs) and halogenated dibenzofurans (HDFs).  40CFR766 identifies the substances and contaminants that must be tested for the presence and quantification of the specified chlorinated or brominated dibenzodioxins and dibenzofurans.  Part 766 also identifies certain precursors conducive to HDD or HDF formation when used to produce other chemicals or products.  Manufacturers and importers of products made from the precursors are required to report which precursors were used to make the chemical product and report process and reaction condition data for the chemical product.

CCL 4 :: The drinking water CCL is a list of contaminants that are currently not subject to any proposed or promulgated national primary drinking water regulations, but are known or anticipated to occur in public water systems. Contaminants listed on the CCL may require future regulation under the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA).  SDWA requires EPA to publish the CCL every five years. SDWA directs the Agency to consider the health effects and occurrence information for unregulated contaminants as the Agency makes decisions to place contaminants on the list. SDWA further specifies that the Agency place those contaminants on the list that present the greatest public health concern related to exposure from drinking water. EPA uses the CCL to identify priority contaminants for regulatory decision making and information collection. Final CCL 4 was announced on November 17, 2016

CWA 304B :: Clean Water Act (CWA) Section 304 requires EPA to develop guidelines for effluent limitations and standards for classes and categories of point sources in support of the National Pollution and Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permits program as required in CWA Section 402.  These guidelines establish the degree of effluent reduction attainable through both the application of the best practicable control technology currently available and the best control measures and practices achievable.

StringWithMarkup.String: Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act Section 313

nodes.description: EPCRA 313 :: The Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA), enacted on October 17, 1986, represents a significant first step toward a major federal role in areas previously regulated by state and local governments. EPCRA was enacted by Congress as a stand-alone provision, Title III, of the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (SARA). Section 313 of EPCRA  requires facilities that exceed a manufacturing, processing, or use threshold for any chemical or chemical category on the list to report information on their handling of that chemical or chemical category to Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) annually.  The collected data, which comprise the Toxic Chemical Release Inventory (TRI), is available to the public.

EPCRA 302 :: Title III of the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (SARA), also known as the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986 (EPCRA), establishes a program designed to encourage state and local planning and preparedness for spills and releases of extremely hazardous substances (EHS).  Under Section 302 of SARA, EPA developed a list of extremely hazardous substances and established threshold planning quantities (TPQs) for each of these substances.  Facilities that have present an EHS in excess of its TPQ must notify its state emergency response commission and participate, as necessary, with the local emergency planning committee in the local emergency planning process.

GHG Proposed Rule :: In response to the FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act (H.R. 2764; Public Law 110161), EPA has proposed a rule that requires mandatory reporting of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from large sources in the United States. 



The proposed rule would collect accurate and comprehensive emissions data to inform future policy decisions. 



In general, EPA proposes that suppliers of fossil fuels or industrial greenhouse gases, manufacturers of vehicles and engines, and facilities that emit 25,000 metric tons or more per year of GHG emissions submit annual reports to EPA.  The gases covered by the proposed rule are carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFC), perfluorocarbons (PFC), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and other fluorinated gases including nitrogen trifluoride (NF3) and hydrofluorinated ethers (HFE).

StringWithMarkup.String: HFCs Regulated under the AIM Act

nodes.description: HFCs AIM :: Hydrofluorocarbons regulated under the American Innovation and Manufacturing Act of 2020. The AIM Act lists 18 HFCs and all isomers as subject to a production and import phasedown, based on their Exchange Value, which is equal to the HFC’s 100-year GWP as listed in IPCC AR4.

CAA112(b) HAP :: The Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112(b)(1) Hazardous Air Pollutants (HAP) lists pollutants that are judged to be hazardous if emitted into the air.  The statute calls for the identification of source categories that emit these hazardous air pollutants, and the subsequent promotion of technology-based emission standards requiring compliance with maximum achievable control technology. The effective date for each of the listed emissions varies according to a number of factors; consult the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) for details.  The source acronym and associated chemical list for this source was revised March 2007.

RCRA Appendix VIII :: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Appendix VIII to 40 CFR 261 lists the toxic constituents that serve as one of the criteria for determining whether a solid waste is a hazardous waste as defined in 40 CFR Part 261.11: Criteria for listing hazardous waste.

RCRA U Waste :: RCRA U Waste is a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) list of commercial chemical products, manufacturing chemical intermediates, or off-specification commercial chemical products or manufacturing chemical intermediates that, when disposed (or when formulations containing any one of these as a sole active ingredient are disposed) unused, become hazardous wastes pursuant to RCRA 3001.  These wastes are also subject to regulation under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act [CERCLA (40 CFR 302.4)].

RCRA F Waste :: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) identifies a list of hazardous wastes from non-specific sources (i.e. not defined by a specific industry) pursuant to RCRA Part 3001. These wastes contain one or more constituents that are considered to be Ignitable Waste, Corrosive Waste, Reactive Waste, Toxicity Characteristic Waste, Acute Hazardous Waste, or Toxic Waste.  The hazardous constituents in each waste can be found in Appendix VII to Part 261 -- Basis for Listing Hazardous Waste.  Hazardous wastes from non-specific sources are identified by a hazardous waste code with F as the initial character.  RCRA wastes are also subject to regulation under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) in 40CFR302.4 and to the exclusion limits for acutely hazardous waste established in 40CFR261.5.

RCRA K Waste :: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) identifies a catagorized list of hazardous wastes from specific sources (i.e. industry or process wastes) pursuant to RCRA 3001.  These wastes contain one or more constituents that are considered to be Ignitable Waste, Corrosive Waste, Reactive Waste, Toxicity Characteristic Waste, Acute Hazardous Waste, or Toxic Waste.  The hazardous constituents in each waste can be found in Appendix VII to Part 261 -- Basis for Listing Hazardous Waste. Hazardous wastes from specific sources are identified by a hazardous waste code with K as the initial character.  RCRA wastes are also subject to regulation under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) in 40CFR302.4 and to the exclusion limits for acutely hazardous waste established in 40CFR261.5.

StringWithMarkup.String: Health and Safety Data Reporting - By Category

nodes.description: TSCA 8D HSDR (c) :: The Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) Section 8(d) requires facilities that engage in, or propose to engage in, the manufacture, processing or importation of a substance or mixture listed in 40 CFR 716.120 to submit health and safety studies for those substances or mixtures.  Reports on these studies must be submitted on, or subsequent to, the date the substance was listed, and include any studies conducted for 10 years prior to the substance being listed.  The TSCA 8D HSDR list includes substances that must be reported under the Health and Safety Data Rule (HSDR).  Categories of  chemicals are listed in this section with examples of the category components.  Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) Registry Numbers not in the CFR have been provided.

Reports on these studies must be submitted on, or subsequent to, the date the substance was listed, and include any studies conducted for 10 years prior to the substance being listed. nodes.description: TSCA 8D HSDR (a) :: The Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) Section 8(d) requires facilities, that engage in or propose to engage in the manufacture, processing or importation of a substance or mixture listed in 40 CFR 716.120, to submit health and safety studies for those substances or mixtures.  Reports on these studies must be submitted on, or subsequent to, the date the substance was listed, and include any studies conducted for 10 years prior to the substance being listed. StringWithMarkup.String: Health and Safety Data Reporting Rule Terminations

nodes.description: TSCA 8D TERM :: TSCA 8(d) Health and Safety Data Reporting Rule Terminations (TERM) is a list of chemicals for which the 8d requirement for Health and Safety Data Reporting has been terminated. The chemicals listed for 8(d) TERM in this database were derived from the Chemicals On Reporting Rules (CORR) database maintained by the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics.

FIFRA-Inerts :: Under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA), all pesticides sold or distributed in the United States must be registered with EPA. Because of concern that some inert ingredients might also cause adverse effects to humans and the environment, EPA outlined its strategy for regulating inert ingredients in 1987. EPA categorized inert ingredients into four toxicological categories; List 1-Inerts of toxicological concern, List 2-Potentially toxic inerts/high priority for testing, List 3-Inerts of unknown toxicity, and List 4-Inerts of minimal concern. In 1989, EPA subdivided List 4 into two lists. List 4 became List 4A, representing minimal risk inert ingredients. List 4B was created to represent inert ingredients for which EPA had sufficient data to conclude that their current use patterns in pesticide products will not adversely affect the environment. Substances without Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) Registry Numbers have not been added to the Chemical Registry.

StringWithMarkup.String: Motor Vehicle Emission and Fuel Standards

nodes.description: CAA 202A :: Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 202(a), the National Emissions Standards Act, requires EPA to develop standards applicable to the emission of any air pollutant from any class or classes of new motor vehicles or new motor vehicle engines which contribute to air pollution and which may reasonably be anticipated to endanger public health or welfare.  In establishing classes or categories of vehicles or engines for purposes of regulations under CAA, EPA may base such classes or categories on gross vehicle weight, horsepower, type of fuel used or other appropriate factors. chemical list reviewed August 2005, no changes required.

CAA 109 :: Clean Air Act Section 109 requires EPA to develop and maintain primary and secondary ambient air quality standards for prescribed air pollutants.  The national primary ambient air quality standards define levels of air quality which the Administrator judges are necessary, with an adequate margin of safety, to protect the public health.  National secondary ambient air quality standards define levels of air quality which the Administrator judges necessary to protect the public welfare from any known or anticipated adverse effects of a pollutant.  The pollutants and promulgated standards can be found in the 40CFR parts 50.4 through 50.12.



Information resource substance list updated July 2005, from 40CFR50 (CFR 2005-2004, Revised as of July 1, 2004).

NPDES :: The identified chemicals may be required to be sampled as part of the NPDES permit application, and this data may be used in, but is not limited to, the development of a permit limit. Note that NPDES permits may include effluent limitations for chemicals that are not on this list.

SDWA NPDWR :: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) of 1974 required the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to develop regulations for substances found in drinking water which, in the judgement of the Administrator, may have an adverse effect on human health.  This list includes substances subject to the National Primary Drinking Water Regulations (NPDWR).  The effective regulation date for each of the listed substances varies according to a number of factors.  Consult the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) for details.  Chemical Abstract Service Registry (CAS) Numbers not in the CFR have been provided.

SDWA NSDWR :: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) required the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to develop regulations to control contaminants in drinking water that primarily affect the aesthetic qualities relating to the public acceptance of drinking water.  These regulations are not federally enforceable but are intended as guidelines to the States.  The Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) includes a list of chemical substances and water quality parameters that are subject to the National Secondary Drinking Water Regulations (NSDWR).  Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) Numbers were not included in the CFR and have been added for the chemical substances included in the regulation.

TSCA 12(b) Export :: Section 12(b) of TSCA requires that any person who exports or intends to export a chemical substance or mixture that is subject to certain rules or orders under TSCA submit a notification regarding the export to EPA. EPA regulations implementing section 12(b) appear at 40 CFR Part 707 Subpart D. Under these regulations, substances and mixtures that require export notification are those for which: (1) data are required under section 4 or 5(b)2; (2) an order has been issued under section 5; (3) a rule has been proposed or promulgated under section 5 or 6; or (4) action is pending or relief has been granted under section 5 or 7 of TSCA. Unlike many other reporting requirements under TSCA, impurities are not exempt from reporting regardless of their concentration or amount.

StringWithMarkup.String: Organic Hazardous Air Pollutants National Emission Standards

nodes.description: CAA112(b) HON :: Hazardous Organic National Emission Standard for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAP) applies to chemical manufacturing process units that are: (1) Part of a major source as defined in section 112 of the Act; (2) produce as a primary product a SOCMI chemical listed in table 1 of subpart F; and (3) use as a reactant or manufacture as a product, by-product, or co-product one or more of the organic 'HAP's listed in table 2 of subpart F.  For the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturing Industry (SOCMI) source category, a source comprises all the SOCMI chemical manufacturing process units that are subject to the rule and are located at contiguous or adjoining properties under common control. The chemical list on this list are derived from Table 1 to Subpart F--Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturing Industry Chemicals, and Table 2 to Subpart F--Organic Hazardous Air Pollutants 40 CFR Part 63 [Federal Register: April 22, 1994] page 118-126.

StringWithMarkup.String: Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) Manufacturing, Processing, Distribution in Commerce, and Use Prohibitions

nodes.description: PCB List :: Concern over the toxicity and persistence in the environment of Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) led Congress in 1976 to enact Section 6(e) of the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) that included among other things, prohibitions on the manufacture, processing, and distribution in commerce of PCBs. Thus, TSCA legislated true cradle to grave (i.e., from manufacture to disposal) management of PCBs in the United States. PCBs are mixtures of synthetic organic chemicals with the same basic chemical structure and similar physical properties ranging from oily liquids to waxy solids. Due to their non-flammability, chemical stability, high boiling point and electrical insulating properties, PCBs were used in hundreds of industrial and commercial applications including electrical, heat transfer, and hydraulic equipment; as plasticizers in paints, plastics and rubber products; in pigments, dyes and carbonless copy paper and many other applications.

TSCA 8A PAIR :: EPA promulgated the generic section 8(a) Preliminary Assessment Information Rules (PAIR) under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) in June 1982, authorizing EPA to collect information to identify, assess and manage human health and environmental risks from chemical substances, mixtures, and categories.  Manufacturers and importers of substances listed under this part must submit a standardized reporting form for each site at which they manufacture or import a listed chemical substance.  EPA evaluates the potential for adverse human health and environmental effects caused by the manufacture or importation of the substance.  The chemicals listed for 8(a) PAIR in this database were derived from the Chemicals On Reporting Rules (CORR) database maintained by the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics.

SARA 110 :: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), as amended by the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA), requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) to develop and revise periodically the CERCLA Priority List of Hazardous Substances, also referred to as the ATSDR Substance Priority List (SPL). This list includes substances most commonly found at facilities on the CERCLA National Priorities List (NPL) that have been deemed to pose the greatest threat to public health. The revised list contains 275 hazardous substances. Once a substance has been listed, it is a candidate to become the subject of a toxicological profile prepared by the ATSDR, and it may be targeted for priority data needs.

CAA 602 :: Title VI of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 provides for the phaseout of ozone-depleting substances. Regulations promulgated under various provisions of this act are consistent with the United States obligations under the 1987 and subsequent revisions of the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer (Montreal Protocol). Under Section 602 of Title VI, the Agency was directed to issue two lists of ozone-depleting chemicals. List one, (Class I chemicals), includes all fully halogenated Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), three halons, carbon tetrachloride, methyl chloroform, and all isomers of these compounds except 1,1,2-Trichloroethane. Methyl bromide and hydrobromochlorocarbons (HBFCs) were added to the list of Class I chemicals under the Accelerated Phaseout Rule. The second list (Class II chemicals) includes all hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) and their isomers. See Appendix A and Appendix B to Subpart A of 40 CFR 82.

StringWithMarkup.String: Radiation Protection: 40 CFR 190: Protection Standards for Nuclear Power Operations

nodes.description: Nuclear Power Operations :: This regulation limits the radiation releases and doses to the public from the normal operations of nuclear power plants and other uranium fuel cycle facilities - the facilities involved in the manufacture and use of uranium fuel for generating electrical power.

StringWithMarkup.String: Radiation Protection: 40 CFR 191: Protection Standards for Management and Disposal of Spent Fuel, High Level and Transuranic Wastes

nodes.description: Spent Nuclear Fuel, High Level, and Transuranic Wastes :: This regulation sets environmental standards for public protection from the management and disposal of spent nuclear fuelHelpspent nuclear fuelFuel that has been withdrawn from a nuclear reactor after use. It is still highly radioactive., high-level radioactive wastesHelphigh-level radioactive wasteHighly radioactive materials produced as a byproduct inside nuclear reactors. Other highly radioactive materials can be designated as high-level waste, if they require permanent isolation. and wastes that contain elements with atomic numbers higher than uranium (transuranic wastes). The standards apply to the management and storage of these materials at any facility regulated by the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) or its Agreement States that is not subject to 40 CFR Part 190. They also apply to the management and storage of these materials at facilities operated by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and not regulated by NRC or its Agreement States (with the exception of the proposed Yucca Mountain facility).

nodes.description: CAA 111 :: Under Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 111, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is authorized to establish new source performance standards (NSPS) to impose federal technology-based requirements on emissions from new or modified major stationary sources of pollution.  EPA has established NSPS for a number of industry categories including municipal waste combustors, Portland cement plants, asphalt concrete plants, incinerators, petroleum refineries, and municipal solid waste landfills.  The purpose of the NSPS for emissions is to ensure that certain EPA-identified sources are designed, built, and operated in a manner that reflects the best demonstrated technology and retains economic feasibility in a uniform manner across the country.  The emissions that are regulated are listed. The chemical list associated with CAA 111 was updated in the SRS September 2005, from 2005-2004 40CFR60.

TSCA 12(c) :: 12C - indicates a substance that is prohibited to be exported from the Unites States under TSCA section 12(c). 

Frank R. Lautenberg Chemical Safety for the 21st Century Act (the Act), which amended the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) was enacted on June 22, 2016. Effective January 1, 2020, the statute prohibits export of: Mercury (I) chloride or calomel; mercury (II) oxide; mercury (II) sulfate; mercury (II) nitrate; and cinnabar or mercury sulphide, unless those mercury compounds are exported to member countries of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development for environmentally sound disposal, on the condition that no mercury or mercury compounds so exported are to be recovered, recycled, or reclaimed for use, or directly reused, after such export.

TSCA Section 4 imposes testing requirements on manufacturers (including importers), as well as processors of chemical substances subject to a test rule. Manufacturers, however, are primarily responsible for testing. Under EPA’s regulations, manufacturers will be responsible for testing where testing is necessary to assess risks that arise primarily from manufacturing, from both processing and manufacturing, or from distribution, use, and/or disposal activities related to the chemical substance. Testing obligations will be imposed on processors where the testing is being conducted to evaluate the risks associated with processing of the chemical, or where no manufacturer submits a notice of intent to conduct testing.
Substances proposed for testing under TSCA section 4
Substances proposed under TSCA 5(a) Significant New Use Rule

TSCA 5(a) Final SNUR :: TSCA 5(a)(2)- Significant New Use Rules (SNURs) authorizes EPA to determine that a use of a chemical substance is a significant new use.  After determination of a significant new use, Section 5(a)(1)(B) of TSCA requires that a notice be submitted to EPA at least 90 days before manufacture, importation, or processing of the chemical substance for that use, providing EPA an opportunity to evaluate the intended use, and if necessary, take regulatory action to prohibit or limit that activity before it occurs.  The chemicals listed for 5(a)(2) SNUR in this database were derived from the Chemicals On Reporting Rules (CORR) database maintained by the Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics.  The list does not represent all of the chemicals that are the subject of a SNUR.

One outcome of EPA's review of a PMN or MCAN for a new chemical substance or review of a SNUN for a significant new use is the issuance of an order under section 5(e) of TSCA. Most TSCA section 5(e) Orders issued by EPA are Consent Orders that are negotiated with the submitter of the notification. If, following EPA’s review of the submitted notification, the Agency makes one of the following determinations, EPA must issue an order under TSCA section 5(e) that prohibits or limits the manufacture, processing, distribution in commerce, use and disposal of the chemical substance.

• the information in the notice is insufficient to allow the Agency to make a reasoned evaluation of the health and environmental effects of the new chemical substance or the significant new use, or

• in the absence of sufficient information, the manufacture, processing, distribution in commerce, use or disposal of the chemical may present an unreasonable risk to health or the environment, without consideration of costs or other non-risk factors, including an unreasonable risk to a potentially exposed subpopulation identified as relevant to the Administrator under the conditions of use, or

• the chemical substance is or will be produced in substantial quantities and will either enter the environment in substantial quantities or there may be significant or substantial human exposure to the substance.

One outcome of EPA's review of a PMN or MCAN for a new chemical substance or review of a SNUN for a significant new use is the issuance of an order under section 5(f) of TSCA. If, following EPA’s review of the submitted notification, the Agency determines that the chemical substance presents an unreasonable risk of injury to health or the environment, then EPA may issue an order under TSCA section 5(f) to prohibit or limit the manufacture, processing, distribution in commerce, use and disposal of the chemical substance.  TSCA section 5(f) orders can either be Consent Orders that are negotiated with the submitter or unilateral orders issued by EPA.

TSCA Inv :: The Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) was enacted by Congress in 1976 and amended in 2016, and provides EPA authority to regulate certain new and existing chemicals commercialized in the United States for non-exempt purpose. Section 8(b) of TSCA requires EPA to compile, keep current, and publish a list of each chemical substance that is commercialized in the US for a TSCA use. The original TSCA Inventory was published in 1979 and included chemicals existing in US commerce at the time TSCA was first enacted.  New chemicals are added to the Inventory when a Notice of Commencement is received for chemicals reported to the EPA under TSCA Section 5 through the Pre-Manufacture Notification (PMN) process.

TSCA 4 ECA :: The creation of an Enforceable Consent Agreement (ECA) requires the development of a formal agreement between EPA, industry, and other interested parties on what testing must be conducted. The formal ECA process began in 1992 when EPA publicly announced an initiative to encourage members of the U.S. chemical industry to submit testing offers to conduct needed testing under public ECA procedures on chemicals for which EPA had not yet issued final Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) section 4 test rules. ECAs allow greater flexibility in the design of the testing program (e.g., test methods can be negotiated).

CWA 307A :: The Clean Water Act (CWA) Toxic Pollutant list from the 40CFR401.15 contains 65 analytes.  The list was developed as part of the 1976 Consent Decree [NRDC et al v. Train, 8 ERC 2120] and was released in Appendix A of the decree.  CWA Section 307 requires EPA to compile a list of chemicals for which an effluent standard is being developed.

StringWithMarkup.String: Underground Injection Control Program CFR parts 144 AND 146

nodes.description: Underground Injection Control Program :: This part sets forth technical criteria and standards for the Underground Injection Control Program. This part should be read in conjunction with 40 CFR parts 124 and 145, which also apply to UIC programs. 40 CFR part 145 describes the elements of an approvable State program and procedures for EPA approval of State participation in the permit programs. 40 CFR part 124 describes the procedures the Agency will use for issuing permits under the covered programs. Certain of these procedures will also apply to State-administered programs as specified in 40 CFR part 145.

StringWithMarkup.String: Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Regulation (3) for Public Water Systems

nodes.description: UCMR3 :: The 1996 Amendments to the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) require EPA to establish criteria for a program to monitor unregulated contaminants and to publish the Drinking Water Contaminant Candidate List (CCL). In April 2012, EPA published third Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR 3). The UCMR 3 required monitoring for 30 contaminants using EPA and/or consensus organization analytical methods during 2013-2015.  EPA established three lists of contaminants based on the availability of analytical methods: List 1 for those with established analytical methods; List 2 for those where analytical methods are being refined; and List 3 for those where methods are being developed.

StringWithMarkup.String: Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Regulation for Public Water Systems

nodes.description: UCMR 1999 :: The 1996 Amendments to the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) require EPA to establish criteria for a program to monitor unregulated contaminants and to publish the Drinking Water Contaminant Candidate List (CCL). In September 1999, EPA published a revision to the Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Regulation (UCMR) which established a new and shorter list of contaminants to be monitored. Based on monitoring results, EPA can decide whether or not to regulate and establish standards for unregulated contaminants in drinking water. EPA established three lists of contaminants based on the availability of analytical methods: List 1 for those with established analytical methods; List 2 for those where analytical methods are being refined; and List 3 for those where methods are being developed.

StringWithMarkup.String: Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR 2) for Public Water Systems

nodes.description: UCMR2 :: The 1996 Amendments to the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) require EPA to establish criteria for a program to monitor unregulated contaminants and to publish the Drinking Water Contaminant Candidate List (CCL). In January 2007, EPA publihed second Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR 2). The UCMR 2 required monitoring for 25 contaminants using five analytical methods during 2008-2010.  EPA established three lists of contaminants based on the availability of analytical methods: List 1 for those with established analytical methods; List 2 for those where analytical methods are being refined; and List 3 for those where methods are being developed. UCMR2 did not include List 3 chemicals.

UCMR 4 :: The 1996 Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) amendments require that once every five years EPA issue a new list of no more than 30 unregulated contaminants to be monitored by public water systems (PWSs).



The fourth Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR 4) was signed by EPAs Administrator on November 30, 2015 and is being submitted for publication in the Federal Register. 

UCMR 4 requires monitoring for 30 chemical contaminants/groups between 2018 and 2020 using analytical methods developed by EPA, consensus organizations or both. This monitoring provides a basis for future regulatory determinations and, as warranted, actions to protect public health.

StringWithMarkup.String: Water Programs: 40 CFR 117: Determination of Reportable Quantities for Hazardous Substances

nodes.description: Determination of Reportable Quantities for Hazardous Substances :: This regulation sets forth a determination of the reportable quantity for each substance designated as hazardous in 40 CFR part 116. The regulation applies to quantities of designated substances equal to or greater than the reportable quantities, when discharged into or upon the navigable waters of the United States, adjoining shorelines, into or upon the contiguous zone, or beyond the contiguous zone as provided in section 311(b)(3) of the Act.

nodes.description: Water Quality Guidance for the Great Lakes System :: This part constitutes the Water Quality Guidance for the Great Lakes System (Guidance) required by section 118(c)(2) of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) as amended by the Great Lakes Critical Programs Act of 1990 (Pub. L. 101-596, 104 Stat. 3000 et seq.). The Guidance in this part identifies minimum water quality standards, antidegradation policies, and implementation procedures for the Great Lakes System to protect human health, aquatic life, and wildlife.
